docs.lead_paragraph: A chart yesterday with a front-page article about plans of the American Association of Retired Persons to license its name to health maintenance organizations misstated the organization's 1994 revenue from insurance fees and related interest income. It was $146.1 million, not $164.9 million.

docs.lead_paragraph: David D. Petersen, one of the country's leading experts on financial planning for the seriously ill, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. Mr. Petersen, who lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, was 54. The cause was complications of AIDS, said his sister, Sharon Shinsky of Largo, Fla.

headline.main: David Petersen, 54, Pioneer Of Financial Plans for the Ill

docs.lead_paragraph: As 150 clerical workers reach the 20-day mark in their strike against Barnard College, the exuberance they once showed is clearly flagging. Support from faculty and students has ebbed, no new negotiations are scheduled and the workers' savings are shrinking, despite the $150 in weekly strike benefits their union pays them. Indeed, some strikers admit that they have lost more money by walking out than they would have gained had Barnard given in to all their demands.

headline.main: Barnard College Clerical Workers' Strike Goes On Despite FlaggingSupport

docs.lead_paragraph: The week after the White House settled its budget squabbles with Congress is a good time to assess President Clinton's stewardship of the economy. He came into office promising to bring a consensus style of policy-making to the White House -- no longer would a budget director like Richard Darman, who served under President Bush, bully everyone in sight. He also promised to direct Federal spending away from wasteful programs and toward future-looking investments in training people. How has he done? The record is mixed. He had many small successes and, in health and welfare reform, a few spectacular failures. On balance, Mr. Clinton did little harm and allowed the economy to prosper. That is not an exciting grade sheet. But it is a responsible one.

docs.lead_paragraph: A small but growing number of influential Republicans, some close to Bob Dole's Presidential campaign, believe that Mr. Dole should distance himself from the Senate -- perhaps even step down as majority leader -- and focus on broader themes that engage the public. With Mr. Dole trailing President Clinton by at least 20 points in the latest national opinion polls, his campaign counting its pennies and concern rising about Mr. Dole's abilities as a campaigner, many of his supporters think the key to turning around his fortunes is for him to abandon the so-called Rotunda strategy and concentrate solely on running for President.

headline.main: More in G.O.P. Say Dole's Senate Role Hinders Campaign

docs.lead_paragraph: A.A.R.P. Plans to License Managed-Care Health Plans In a move expected to prompt millions of elderly Americans to join managed health plans, the American Association of Retired Persons will begin licensing its name to health-maintenance organizations across the country later this year.
docs.snippet: A.A.R.P. Plans to License Managed-Care Health Plans In a move expected to prompt millions of elderly Americans to join managed health plans, the American Association of Retired Persons will begin licensing its name to health-maintenance organizations...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a move that could prompt millions of older Americans to join managed health plans, the American Association of Retired Persons will begin licensing its name to health maintenance organizations across the country later this year. The 33-million-member association, best known as a lobbying group for the elderly, is already a big player in the insurance business, endorsing selected auto and homeowners policies, and insurance that pays medical bills not covered by Medicare. In return, it receives substantial revenue from royalties and related income -- $146 million in 1994, which provided 38 percent of its budget.

headline.main: A.A.R.P. Will License Its Name To Managed Health Care Plans
